bow: my daughter wants to skip the 8th grade and the school says she competent enough academically should let her my daughter is finishing up 7th grade having been stellar student her entire academic career she earned top grades and she also student athlete active in track and cross country running and member of the drama club and the band she is more mature than her peer group she had lot to deal with in her young life including the loss of her dad six years ago after prolonged illness she asked me if she could skip 8th grade because most of her friends are year ahead of her in school but think that lousy reason to skip grade high school is characterized by change and the friends she has now may not be her besties year from now also concerned that the other student athletes would have one year competitive edge on my daughter and that she lose out on at least one or two performances with the drama club my first instinct is to say no but told her that would consider the question fairly so asking moms what do you think update she did want to wait until dinner she been texting and skyping with her friends all day to come up with her lists and she decided all by herself that she does want to skip 8th grade after all we talked it over and reiterated some of the points you kind ladies made was actually leaning toward letting her skip at one point think was even trying to talk her into it but guess the point is moot now her reasons for not wanting to skip are in her order of importance she wants that extra year to grow and train and hopefully win some sports scholarships to fund her education told her about redshirting but she does want to repeat the 7th grade for the sake of college money bit of disappointment that she does want to miss the class trip to memphis ha called that one her friends in drama club who are graduating this year told her the thing they would miss most about school was being in drama club and that she nuts for wanting to miss even one production and they would give anything to be in just one more show and think heard one of them crying oh drama club she the smartest kid in the class but if she skipped she would be anymore and she likes being special she likes not having to spend lot of time studying because it gives her time for other other interests school is easy do want it to be too hard do have time for more homework http i0 kym cdn com photos images original 000 284 529 e65 gif we also talked about ap classes and she just as happy to do that and get headstart on college instead of missing out on year of her childhood and we left the door open for future grade skipping in case she changes her mind proud of her for making an informed decision she had more reasons but those were the top thanks for all your help mommit lt say let her think one thing to consider is her social emotional experience which she indicates is stronger in the year above she can still have great experience in her assigned grade but would it be worth watching your best friends have fun without you at things like prom and graduation kids adjust but it seems she has strong preference also as far as student athletics her performance could change in minute and she would likely be on junior varsity team in hs which is very typical for young players in hs she can always advance to varsity team honestly she would be skipping middle school not anything in high school my point is that high school is where the memories are made and challenge are really faced think if she stayed in assigned grade she would be bored and resentful give her challenge but explain that this advancement is to hang out with friends and there will be consequences for not putting in hs level work in class also drama club is always more fun in high school did theater in hs and ms and without doubt loved hs more good luck to you both was in very similar situation when was her age however my parents did not let me advance can say it was an awful decision was so bored academically let everything go did care basically gave up and then did put any effort in when did get to the 9th grade because what had been taught was there was no rewards for your hard work and achievements so why bother kids can adjust to the social aspect of skipping grade much like they can if they were to be held back you can be there for her if she starts to struggle socially you mentioned you think she more mature use that and let her know she can always come to you if things get difficult and you ll help her out edit word if she frustrated with the work and losing interest academically would let her it not an irreversible decision if it does work out she can go back if it just about being in the same class as her friends would think further on it if she did skip would also consider sending her abroad for an exchange year between high school and university so she ends up the same age as her peers later on do think possibly winning less at athletics is good reason to hold her back college has drama club too did let you advance or did would say if you can ask the question is she emotionally mature enough to skip grade and be with the older kids and the answer is yes then the decision could be pretty simple considering that she definitely seems intellectually mature enough and she already has friends that age another consideration however are her peers in 9th grade that are not her friends young teenagers can be total assholes and would they be hard on your daughter because she skipped 8th grade perhaps they resent her and or find something to tease her about this absolutely might not happen but could be worth exploring with her and maybe trusted teacher or guidance counsellor thank you for your thoughts she really is more mature than her age group and we had already planned to enroll her in ap classes when she gets to high school if she skips the 8th grade she ll have to go to summer school to catch up and she already got cross country and band camp going on and believe me ve asked her many times if she like to give something up but she enjoys all her activities and she seems to thrive on being busy thank you and grateful that we do have the kind of relationship we where can talk things out she very independent and self motivated she takes her grades very seriously more than do and she conscientious about being on time and prepared for all her activities more than am in sixth grade she was being bullied by another girl in her class and her solution was to make an appointment for herself and the bully with the guidance counselor the other girl was very surprised to hear her own name being called down to the office but the two of them managed to work things out only found out about it after the fact when the guidance counselor called me to let me know what was going on think that speaks volumes about her level of maturity and problem solving skills initially was against the idea but leaning toward it now you make very good point supposed we could try summer school and she how far she gets and whether she still likes the idea afterward that is exactly the point was wondering how to make teenage assholery she dealt successfully with bully in the past but that was middle school and high school is whole different ball game she very results oriented kid but worry that she might be pushing herself too hard didnt* words are hard in the morning one piece to consider is how mature will she be when she graduates and goes to college we kept our daughter back year to start kindergarten because just could imagine sending 17 year old to college on her own not yet mom due this june but when was kid skipped from 6th grade math to 8th grade math only math no other subjects although truthfully probably could have skipped ahead in other areas let me ask you this how does she respond to frustration how do you think she might respond to possibly no longer being the smartest kid in the class and even being behind most of the class in very the beginning of the school year my math class was tested on topics that were review for everyone else but were brand new to me because they learned it all in the class skipped so failed that quiz the first time that ever happened to me the teacher did not volunteer me any support and was not used to asking for help so had to figure it out on my own and of course everything we learned later built on those concepts so it is crucial at the beginning of the school year to realize that since she advanced year she is no longer ahead of everyone else she is actually behind and she needs to work bit harder than everyone else in the beginning just to get on the same page for other subjects like english this may not be problem but for math and science she may need extra help and encouragement from you and or tutor in the beginning if you decide to go this route and that another thing she ll be 17 when she graduates if she skips grade she ll be 16 when she graduates her birthday is in august so she already year younger and quite bit smaller than her peer group at least the university she wants to attend is right here in town and she be able to live at home should also mention that did figure it out eventually and wound up with that semester instead of my usual often find that maturity does not match age ve known 18 year olds who you swear was only 16 and vise versa even the face value of maturity is no guarantee they re ready for college kids are assessed on case by case basis say let her my daughter is in the year old class at school she the youngest too at she loves to try and keep up with the other kids she very coordinated recognizes letters and is exceeding milestones consistently there are some things you ca help all you can do is feed their little minds in this case feed your daughter expanding mind if you have already noticed she mature beyond her time the death of her father has forever changed her path she experienced trauma that most of us wo understand until our children have children sounds like you two are very connected does she have strong father figure in her life good luck to you both right the counselor already told her she ll have to go to summer school this summer to catch up with what the 8th graders have already learned she seems enthusiastic about the idea she loves school even though she already got band camp and cross country for most of the summer too she only ever failed one test and it did upset her but it was more the format of the test than the fact that she failed she knew the material and agreed the test was badly designed so many kids in the class failed that test the teacher threw it out her first soccer team did win single game all season but she always say something about fresh air exercise and everybody gets snack anyway she was actually one of the worst scorers and the worst goalkeeper on her team but she loved the running part so we went back week after week losing did seem to bother her she not the best runner on her team either but she tells me she only running against her own time and not competing with anyone but herself she does get frustrated easily but she stubborn when she thinks she right and impossible to argue with because said so has never been good enough for her she always needed reason it frustrating for me but she seems fine with it well if you let her do it and she fails then it could be an amazing amazing learning opportunity it sounds like she is someone who has big plans in life something like this will only help to shape her character as far as an escape plan is she allowed to repeat grade nine if she does like it or is achieving the results she wants sometimes she reminds me of me at that age and sometimes do understand her at all since her dad died ve found someone else and we re managing to cobble together our two families his children are all grown and he great dad she also very close with her uncle who moved in with me for year to help take care of things thanks for your thoughts it looks like in the minority here but ll chime in anyway as teacher can say that ve taught number of students that have skipped grade academically many have done quite fine as the reason for their advancement was academic achievement but socially and emotionally can *almost* always pick them out in the crowd their ability to cope with challenges socially and the oft changing dynamic of high school social interactions has often left them either isolated or noticeably awkward interactions with teachers and adults can be noticeably immature pouting emotionally driven rather than logically and sometimes they hit wall intellectually where certain courses require more advance level of thinking that their brans just are ready for yet would talk to her teachers the ones you feel know her best to get feel for this possibility not just academically but socially as well the guidance counselor said she ll have to attend summer school and based on the results she ll either be allowed to skip 8th grade or not guess it would hurt to let her try she definitely has plan last year she decided she wanted to be vegetarian so made her do some research and figure out how to get enough protein into her diet without meat she presented me with meal plans recipes and stacks of studies she found after consult with our family doctor let her go for it it sparked an interest in nutrition and she decided on it for her field of study ll admit some of the smoothies she makes are pretty darn tasty and she tells me the kale banana sweet potato one is nutritional powerhouse think you should follow her lead on this one if she feels this strongly about it it best to get out of her way and see how it pans out it may be wonderful or it may be bust but she ll always resent you if you hold her back plus she sounds like kid who resilient enough to deal with the challenges that come with grade skipping and she has supportive mom to help her pick up the pieces if it falls apart so take deep breath and tell her you support her no matter what she decides good luck to you both deleted thank you was hoping teacher would chime in have spoken with her teachers or her coaches yet but have talked to the guidance counselor going to line up some meetings this week though and get their thoughts too the guidance counselor is all for letting her go to summer school and then assessing the outcome before we make final determination inclined to make somewhat final determination before let her go to summer school to do otherwise smacks of starting project you have no intention of finishing think that forcing her to stay behind year would leave her bored and disenchanted with learning worse she could get the idea that she does have to work hard to succeed she just naturally smart and does have to do homework or study like the other kids to do well on tests you do want her developing the idea that she smarter than her peers different an exception or thinking that nobody else is as smart as her if you leave her with peers that are grade below her academically that might happen she independent and self motivated now but what about after few more years when she at the top of the class and she figures out she does have to work hard to get there big trouble bumping her up by grade think would challenge her academically and socially and set her up better for the future think she ll be happier too it ll be harder than staying in the same grade but she wo be bored out of her mind sports and drama performances are important but not at the cost of her education it sounds like you re already making lot of decisions for her what university she ll go to how she ll fare bumping up grade in reality you just do know she does know either things change think you guys should try it out and if it does work you can send her back to the lower grade to me it sounds like your school district counselor is good resource and you are the type of mom to investigate things and that she is the type of kid to persevere this is the ideal combination and bet she will do well high school is rough on everyone for the most part being academically bored wo help her might as well put her at the right academic level to challenge her somewhat understand your concern about teenage assholery unfortunately it just part of high school is it large school if so she will probably find group of kids that she fits in with and do just fine it sounds like she already has core group of friends to start with so she not going in without knowing anyone my bigger concern would be college my sister entered an out of state university at 17 and think it was too early for her would suggest exploring community college or at least local college for her first year skipped first grade and while it was good for me academically it was terrible for me socially the social aspect of grade skipping is typically *the* biggest problem with it given that your daughter already has an established social group that year ahead of her say you should let her try it would let her do summer school and see if she still wants to do it at the end of summer do think of it as failing project as much as doing trial run or doing your research went to college at 17 without skipping grade and it was fine in second masters program now at 33 early grade schoolers are bigger assholes than high schoolers imo that my biggest concern too she wants to take ap classes too so theoretically she could enter university as 16 year old sophomore she had the same friends since grade school but this year since she started cross country and drama club she hanging out with those kids and they re bit older than she is it not huge school there are about 250 kids in her graduating class gt was in very similar situation when was her age however my parents did not let me advance can say it was an awful decision was so bored academically let everything go this was my experience too my parents were given the option to skip me two grades and refused nearly failed out of school entirely after 9th grade when was bored out of my skull say if she *wants* to skip grade let her agreed say if she feels she can handle it and the school says she can let her do it she may need the challenge that is amazing say she is very aware of her own ability and what she can handle agree with the other comment look at it as trial run it was pretty amazing she always been independent but was shocked to find out that she was being bullied and she figured out solution on her own afterward did tell her that she can always come to me if she has any problems no matter what they are and she just shrugged it off and told me she knew that but she did need my help this time her entire attitude can be summed up in her favorite catchphrase do worry mom got this well it is good that she can handle things in an adult manner do worry little that she might be trying to handle things on her own as not to worry you but only say that from my own weird childhood experience and have no idea about how you guys are as family unit which sounds pretty healthy from what can see as long as she knows she can come to you if she feels she really ca handle something that is good would have the same concern except that she always been that way first day of preschool while the other kids were clinging to their moms and crying she walked right into her classroom without backward glance no fear she like that with everything more concerned that she stretching herself too thin trying to do too much we re definitely making this decision together she asked me about it after she talked to her guidance counseler about it apparently she been thinking about it for while ve only just been added to the discussion this weekend so doing little websurfing seeing what kind of studies are available on the topic but it always good idea to get perspective from people who have real world experience for her part she supposed to come up with list of reasons why it great idea to skip grade and another list of why it horrible idea want her to be able to see both sides of the argument she also has to come up with list of her own personal reasons for wanting to skip grade we have date to talk about it again over dinner and then we ll decide whether or not to proceed with the teacher coach meetings skipped grade when was younger never had trouble keeping up with the academics but the social aspect was at times challenging for me doubt anyone thought was going off the rails when first got to high school but was an easy target for kids and adults who wanted to take advantage of others there are lot of tougher social situations that kids face in high school where being year younger does you no favors hormonal changes can lead to anxiety and depression and make even really solid good kid stumble in your situation would look into alternatives get an iep maybe see if there are options for advanced learning try and provide enrichment in other ways teach her to find excellence and push herself when she does feel she is being pushed hard enough would be very reluctant to skip grade unless it seemed to be the only way to keep her from struggling and being bored same we randomly moved to different state my junior year of school was leaps ahead of my peers both academically and psychologically they wanted to place me into senior year but my parents refused she needs to have senior year naturally gravitated towards all of the ap and senior courses and ended up having all senior friends my senior year was *horrible* it was dull lonely and complete waste of year ended up getting really depressed and lost sight of my life goals at the time was working mc job and decided that that was all my life was going to amount to because it was the only place that would appreciate my hard work and intellect as college student athlete would say no if it is only academics you and your daughter are worried about then definitely do it but if you want her to have future in athletics and the greater possibility of scholarship wait until she is in high school they offer ap college classes in lot of high schools which actually count as college credits she can still maintain competitive advantage in sports while challenging herself academically if she wants to go to college she ll need scholarships and think this is something we definitely need to think about while ve been researching this topic found out about practice called redshirting in which children are deliberately held back year to give them competitive advantage depending on how prevalent that practice is my kid could be competing against kids two or three years older than her good confident it might be good for her to not be the absolute best at something and to enjoy the thrill of academic challenge so perhaps that is something else to focus on rather than the negative points you or her teachers decide it not working out part of growing up is learning how to assess the risks and benefits of choices and making those big decisions think this is something benign enough that if it does work out its not the end of the world but it will be big lesson learned if it does work out she ll be happy my daughter is in math classes with older kids so it is entirely possible she ll gives me hope so thanks for that redshirting is not holding her back year as ncaa player she will have five years to actively play four years you have the option to redshirt which means you are part of the team and you practice but do not compete or grayshirt which means you are part of the team but do not practice or compete all you do is focus on academics stay in shape and go to team meetings sure there is more detailed description about the two this is just description from an athletes standpoint however still believe you should not move her up grade if could go back in time actually wish was held back grade especially for football played football wrestling and track was year around athlete although was very good if you look at the statistics athletes born in december and january that are early in age for their grade are more likely to go pro most nfl players are born in december and the reason is they are more developed and stand out from the crowd outperforming the less developed athletes keep her in her current grade and if things are two easy for her and she needs more of challenge have her take advanced classes in high school or have heard of community colleges allowing high school students to take classes on their campus in between before and or after their regular classes
